ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lectures
Live virtual lectures were also recorded.
PPT
The lectures were also recorded so that was also an option
Reading the textbook was helpful to understand the foundations and the proofs behind the concepts we were learning in class, which we often didn't have time to go through in complete detail.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to design and analyze separation methods.
Knowledge of common chemical separation techniques, including distillation, absorption and liquid-liquid extraction.

Great introductory insight into separations and purification processes, with extra focus on the application of principles of thermodynamics and transport phenomena for each separation method. An essential course for any chemical engineer!
Review of thermodynamics and mass transport briefly, single stage separations, cascades, absorption, distillation, liquid-liquid extraction, membrane separations.
Knowledges related to chemical separation

As the title implies, you learn about separation and purification processes, purifying mixtures of substances down into (usually) pure substance and some other mixture. Mathematical models to describe how they function and how efficient they are.

I gained knowledge about how the primary methods of chemical separation are designed and implemented. The course builds off previous CENG courses like thermo and fluids and it is great to be able to apply those subjects in a more advanced context.

You learn about different separation techniques, such as distillation, exchangers, membranes, and the uses of different columns.  There is also a review of thermodynamics and mass transfer at the beginning of the course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was extremely well taught and organized. No improvements necessary.

Strengths: the material is straightforward, and well-taught. The textbook follows what we cover in class very closely, so you can always complete your learning by reading the textbook. The workload is manageable, and the grading is very fair.

Weaknesses: the exams are nothing like the problems in the homework.

One strength of the course was how organized it was. Required readings, homework problems, grading schemes, and all other aspects of the class were clearly outlined at the very beginning of the semester, making it clear that was expected for the course. 

One weakness of the course was the level of engagement. I did not feel very engaged in lectures, and often resorted to watching the recordings of lecture rather than attending them live and 'in-person'
Overall it was a very easy course. The notes and textbook were very clear though the lectures confusing. I wish we could have covered more topics more deeply.
Good class

Honestly this class was exactly what it sounds to be. I came in expecting to learn about Separations and Purification, and that's exactly what I got out of it. It was strong in that respect, and had few weaknesses because it is what it says it is.

Depending on your point of view, this will be either a strength or a weakness and I am not sure where I fall myself: the class is quite fundamental and covered only the most important separations processes. The course was still engaging and at times challenging but it definitely leaves room for you to explore the textbook and other chapters/subjects further outside of the course.
I think it would be helpful for there to be more problems solved during class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was taught very similarly as Professor Zhong's kinetics class, and was equally as effective. No changes necessary.

Since this class is small (about 15 people), you can still get to know the professor and participate during class time.

Engagement could perhaps be improved by asking students to keep their video on.
Great use of recording lectures, using tablet to draw out lecture slides. Very easy to follow along in lecture and was rarely any technical issues.
Recordings were great! I had no qualms with what was done, I thought it was a great format.
Although I attended lecture regularly, the recorded lectures allowed me to review material I was still unclear about.
The course was conducted similarly to how it would have been in person with Professor Zhong using a tablet to write notes.  I felt that this was a good system through the virtual software.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class to any engineering student who could use this as an elective class. It is interesting, well organized, and has a great teacher.
Yes, if you're chemE.

yes, I would recommend to any other chemical engineering major (although its a requirement, so they'll have to take it anyways). It really is a well-structured class and the format is geared towards understanding of the material. Additionally, Mingjiang is always a fantastic and organized lecturer, great at emphasizing the essential information we need to know.
You probably have to take it. Otherwise, the material isn't that interesting.
Yes, great class, a lot of examples used to understand concepts

If you are interested in learning about Separation and Purification Processes, then yes I would recommend it. To the Chemical Engineers, this is a fine course that will use knowledge from other classes and apply it.
This class is generally only taken by senior Chemical engineering majors.  I would say that it is one of the easier required courses of the major.
